body:
HI @lzbj please work with @houshengbo on debugging travis build failure.
I see you added the vcap encrypted file, the file can't be decrypted here:https://travis-ci.org/openwhisk/openwhisk/builds/139972366

Also I think we need to save the not encrypted .json file some where that only us can access not public, give it to @houshengbo this will allow us to update it in the future/

@houshengbo is working on a new repo, and I think the tests and code for catalog will move there https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog
PPG 684
@dubeejw Can you give me a üëç  if this is ready for merge now?
Is there a test that download the CLI via nginx? If not - please add one.
PPG 681 approved.
Previously passed PG but since I changed implementation, new PPG 686.

That's fine if the hit is once but where there are no changes, building the go cli back to back should not take 2 minutes each time. If we can't resolve this, I suggest we pull the go cli distDocker target out of the main gradle file and make it a separate, explicit build step.
Rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/ac3b9f5c6743f2a17e695829944a34eefb0815f1.
PR merged.
@dubeejw - Quick python CLI change review, please
Can we actually implement the functionality? You never really know for how long code sticks around.

@psuter all the http requests in the python cli go through wskutils.py `request` - by sloth principle, since `-i` is a top level parameter, a quick implementation could add a global flag that is toggled by `-i` which predicates the trust exemption in `request`.

@psuter @rabbah - python wsk CLI is being deprecated, so unless there's a fix/feature that's high priority, I'm thinking that the python CLI remains as-is.  This update was only to allow common test code to issue the exact same commands to the Go and python wsk CLIs.
@csantanapr - ready for merge now.  Multiple commits were squashed.  Thanks!
rebase and merged a7c862666b6f380a9395d7d57e6c2ad9d001def0
rebase and merged 558dbd8008d2d3beca38c44cef65b9203791a30e
Is the default in the go cli to allow or reject untrusted SSL?

Here's an inline pull request that implements the feature - if it wasn't just a few lines, I'd say forgo it.

```
diff --git a/tools/cli/wsk b/tools/cli/wsk
index 328ddd9..b598b18 100755
--- a/tools/cli/wsk
+++ b/tools/cli/wsk
@@ -40,7 +40,8 @@ from wskrule import Rule
 from wskpackage import Package
 from wsknamespace import Namespace
 from wsksdk import Sdk
-from wskutil import addAuthenticatedCommand, apiBase, chooseFromArray, resolveNamespace, request, responseError
+from wskutil import addAuthenticatedCommand, apiBase, chooseFromArray, httpRequestProps, resolveNamespace, request, responseError
+

 def main():
     userpropsLocation = os.getenv('WSK_CONFIG_FILE', '%s/.wskprops' % os.path.expanduser('~'))
@@ -54,6 +55,7 @@ def main():
     exitCode = 0
     try:
         args = parseArgs(userprops)
+        httpRequestProps['insecure'] = args.insecure
         apihost = resolveOverrides(whiskprops['CLI_API_HOST'], userprops.get('APIHOST'), args.apihostOverride)
         apiversion = resolveOverrides('v1', userprops.get('APIVERSION'), args.apiversionOverride)

@@ -100,7 +102,7 @@ def parseArgs(props):

     parser.add_argument('--apihost', help='whisk API host', dest='apihostOverride', metavar='hostname')
     parser.add_argument('--apiversion', help='whisk API version', dest='apiversionOverride', metavar='version')
-    parser.add_argument('-i', '--insecure', help='reserved command option', action='store_true')
+    parser.add_argument('-i', '--insecure', help='allow untrusted SSL certificates', action='store_true', default=True)

     Action().getCommands(subparsers, props)
     Activation().getCommands(subparsers, props)
diff --git a/tools/cli/wskutil.py b/tools/cli/wskutil.py
index 88093d5..65be44b 100644
--- a/tools/cli/wskutil.py
+++ b/tools/cli/wskutil.py
@@ -23,6 +23,9 @@ import base64
 import collections
 from urlparse import urlparse

+# global configurations, can control whether to allow untrusted certificates on HTTPS connections
+httpRequestProps = { 'insecure': False }
+
 def supportsColor():
     if (sys.platform != 'win32' or 'ANSICON' in os.environ) and sys.stdout.isatty():
         return True
@@ -55,7 +58,7 @@ def request(method, urlString, body = '', headers = {}, auth = None, verbose = F
     if url.scheme == 'http':
         conn = httplib.HTTPConnection(url.netloc)
     else:
-        if hasattr(ssl, '_create_unverified_context'):
+        if httpRequestProps['insecure']:
             conn = httplib.HTTPSConnection(url.netloc if https_proxy is None else https_proxy, context=ssl._create_unverified_context())
         else:
             conn = httplib.HTTPSConnection(url.netloc if https_proxy is None else https_proxy)
```

What is the default for the GO CLI? (I will go read the code.)

If `-i` is off by default, it means we have to document that all devs (and our READMEs) specify that it is required otherwise connections will fail.

Is the default setting perhaps smart and knows if the IP is a localhost, to use `-i == true` else `false`?

This is probably a setting we can put in the config file. I certainly don't want to type `-i` all the time.
Yes, default rejects untrusted certs.
@houshengbo, we are now building the binaries in the build directoy in the Docker container. See: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/558dbd8008d2d3beca38c44cef65b9203791a30e.
If the feature is actually added to the Python CLI. The tests have to be updated as well.
This preserves existing semantics. Plus you're updating the tests for -i, yes? So no breaking change, agree?
If we actually implement the full -i feature in this PR, and the tests go into another PR, we create a circular dependency between the two different PRs.
note that the code above says: `-i default is True` this is semantic preserving. I will add the inline code above and merge it later - not worth debating this further.

Yeah I agree
As part lf a local build we can set the property
We can added to the propeties like
wsk property set --i true

@mdeuser, completely remove the logic to setup the timestamp from Gradle. Modify the Dockerfile file to build the Go CLI like so: ...-ldflags "-X main.CLI_BUILD_TIME=```date -u '+%Y-%m-%dT%I:%M:%SZ'```"...

Here's the result on the second gradle build: 
BUILD SUCCESSFUL
Total time: 17.792 secs

The problem seems to be that `gradle-2.7` is not available for Ubuntu 16.04. Alternative method to uncover the issue (e.g. for Mac users); attempt to build the following docker image, mimicking the steps in `gradle.sh`:

```
FROM ubuntu:16.04
ENV DEBIAN_FRONTEND noninteractive
RUN apt-get -y update
RUN apt-get install -y software-properties-common
RUN apt-get install -y python-software-properties
RUN add-apt-repository -y ppa:cwchien/gradle
RUN apt-get -y update
RUN apt-cache search gradle
RUN apt-get install -y gradle-2.7
```

The `apt-cache` command shows that the available versions are:

```
gradle - Gradle is a Groovy based build system
gradle-ppa - Gradle is a Groovy based build system
gradle-2.9 - Gradle is a Groovy based build system
gradle-2.10 - Gradle is a Groovy based build system
gradle-2.11 - Gradle is a Groovy based build system
gradle-2.12 - Gradle is a Groovy based build system
gradle-2.13 - Gradle is a Groovy based build system
gradle-2.14 - Gradle is a Groovy based build system
```

...and the `apt-get install` command fails as a consequence.

@pparkkin you can for now almost certainly work around the issue by modifying `tools/ubuntu/gradle.sh` to install `gradle-2.9`, for instance.

We may need to make the installation more robust to variations in available packages, in this case, maybe by bundling a `gradlew` launcher?
Great. Thanks!
LGTM, memo to self to merge ASAP
@psuter: We are in fact bundling a `gradlew` launcher. We use Gradle 2.12 for that, so we should update `ubuntu-setup.sh`

The currently-implemented proposal is to have a new `kind` named "nodejs:default". When this `kind` is specified, the OW backend resolves that to whatever the current default should be (as determined by the mapping in `DefaultRuntimeVersions.scala`).  This mapping can be updated/applied to more runtimes as needed.

Having an explicit alias is useful for situations when the `kind` cannot be determined from the file(s) from which the action is being created. That being said, the CLIs have been updated to use the "nodejs:default" `kind` for .js files when no `kind` was explicitly provided.

Resolving this on the backend allows all clients (CLI, REST, Bluemix, etc.) to make use of this new alias, without duplicating logic for resolving what that alias should mean.

It is important to note that the alias is not recorded as the action's `kind`, but rather the resolved "real" `kind` is stored with the action. This means that once the `kind` is resolved to a real runtime (e.g. "nodejs:6"), that is the `kind` for that action until such point that it is explicitly updated by a client.
Could we instead drop installing gradle altogether and only use `gradlew`? One less dep to manage...

We only have to do one copy command in the Ansible file now:
shell: "docker cp go-cli:/src/github.com/go-whisk-cli/build '{{ go_cli_nginx_dir }}'"

Does it make sense to combine the two prs?

Note: You can update the kind if you also update the exec artifact. You cannot update the kind independently. This is a restriction from the API side. This prevents for example updating a swift action with a kind nodejs.

I'll guess that when you specified the `namespace` on `get` you omitted the leading `/` as in `wsk namespace get x` vs `wsk namespace get /x`. The leading `/` on an namespace is required in all CLI commands that refer to a namespace (rationale being that this indicates a change of a top level "path").

`wsk namespace list` lists namespaces without the leading slash. so for consistency, i'd suggest we either list them with leading `/` or allow `wsk namespace get` to work with no leading `/`.

besides that -- i think think it's irritating to get the content of a different namespace listed when missing the `/` -- an error msg would be more appropriate.

Proposal:   nuke support for ant entirely -- document the gradle/ansible path as "THE" one and only solution.

Rationale:  we don't want to maintain 2 ways of doing things.    Unless we test both one will always rot.
Putting [WIP] as it's missing tests.

Once I discovered that (at least in the Python CLI) `wsk action update` will actually create the action if it does not yet exist, then I just stopped using `wsk action create` entirely. Sadly though, I can't do this with the Go CLI because `update` doesn't support `--kind` at all.

From the OpenWhisk's perspective, to break the dependency on the installation of the catalog packages, I propose to work on the following item(s):

*Remove or replace the catalog installation from the test in OpenWhisk. By far, OpenWhisk installs all the packages by default and there are tests regarding all the package installation. We should either remove them out as well or replace them with some fixtures or mocks. This could be the first step to break the catalog dependencies in OpenWhisk. After this, the Travis CI build to check each PR won't break at the catalog package check.

I will open PR for it and assign to folks who are interested. Feel free to give your comments.

@markusthoemmes build and deployment are connected at least in terms of documentation. Check the current Ubuntu deployment doc:
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/ubuntu-setup/README.md

Then it says:

### Build and Deploy

```
# Build and deploy
ant clean build deploy
```

There should be pre-built docker images published at docker hub, and deployment docs based on those images.

whisk.done() and whisk.async() will be removed for nodejs 6 as part of this pr since they are not necessary now that promises are supported.  However, with the change being made to make nodejs 6 the default in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/738 all async js actions (such as pipe.js etc.....) installed by the install scripts will fail when run.  This is because the install scripts do not specify the kind so nodejs 6 will be used once it becomes the default.  As part of this pr I will update the install scripts to specify the kind to use nodejs for all of the async js actions.  I will will open a new pr to handle converting our existing async js actions to use promises.
@csantanapr - One last check from you and this PR is ready to merge... finally!

@rabbah - I've played around with the Dockerfile a bit and have the following proposal.
- As PhiIippe suggest, I moved the `ARG BUILDTIME` down in the file so that the common tool download/installation is always pulled from the cache.  I also moved the `ADD` command down as well.
- The go-cli build checks for a `WHISK_BUILD_TIMESTAMP` environment variable.  If it exists, it uses that value as the timestamp.  Subsequent builds will use this same timestamp value, and if it is not changed and there are no Go CLI code changes, the build pulls from the cache (10-20 second Go CLI builds).  If that env variable is not set, a timestamp is dynamically generated, causing the Go build to occur (i.e. cache is ignored).

The environment variable can be changed to pull from a file, or gradle property.. Whatever we decide to use as the Whisk-wide build timestamp.. assuming that is still desired.

/cc  @dubeejw @psuter
